title: 110_hr1679
content: The "Caribbean Coral Reef Protection Act" aims to deny financial resources to Cuba and deter foreign investments that threaten US national security, Florida's marine environment, and the Cuban people's well-being. It also seeks to prevent the development of Cuba's petroleum resources. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 is amended to exclude aliens who contribute to Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources off its coast. The Secretary of State must deny visas and exclude from the US any alien who invests over $1,000,000 in enhancing Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources off its coast. Spouses, minor children, or agents of such individuals are also affected. The Secretary may waive this if certifying to congressional committees on a case-by-case basis. The Secretary of State can deny visas and exclude aliens who invest in Cuba's petroleum development. Waivers can be granted on a case-by-case basis to individuals meeting specific criteria. Definitions for terms like 'agent' and 'investment' are provided in this section. The curr_chunk discusses agreements entered into with the Government of Cuba or nongovernmental entities related to petroleum development off Cuba's coast since January 10, 2005. It includes contracts for development, ownership shares, participation in royalties, and the sale of goods or services. The amendment applies to contracts for petroleum resources and related technology. Effective for aliens seeking admission after the enactment date of the Act. The amendment imposes sanctions and prohibits the facilitation of Cuba's petroleum resources development. If the President determines that a person has made an investment of $1,000,000 or more contributing to Cuba's petroleum development, sanctions will be imposed, including prohibiting loans and guarantees and export sanctions. Export sanctions may be imposed on sanctioned persons under various acts, prohibiting the export of goods or technology. Financial institutions may face prohibitions, such as being designated as a primary dealer by the Federal Reserve. Sanctions may include prohibiting financial institutions from serving as government agents or repositories for funds. Procurement of goods or services from sanctioned persons by the US Government is also prohibited. Sanctions will be lifted if the President certifies to Congress that conditions have been met. Sanctions under subsection (a) will end if the President certifies that requirements of the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act have been met. US persons are prohibited from aiding Cuba's petroleum development. The Secretary of State must report on investments exceeding $1,000,000 every 180 days. The Senate committees report on investments exceeding $1,000,000 contributing to Cuba's petroleum development and investments in confiscated US property. Information includes values, identities of investors, proposed investments, and sanctions imposed. The Secretary of State, in consultation with other agencies, must provide annual assessments on the environmental impact of Cuba's petroleum development on submerged lands off Cuba's coast and Florida's marine environment to relevant congressional committees. The Secretary of State will use environmental impact statements as a model for assessing the impact of Cuba's petroleum development on submerged lands and Florida's marine environment. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms used in the Act, including terms like "appropriate congressional committees", "confiscated", "person", "property", and "traffics" as well as terms related to investment in petroleum resources. The Cuban Communist Party is included in the definitions of "agent" and "instrumentality".
